<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"New Infection Chain and ConfuserEx-Based Obfuscation for DarkCloud Stealer","name":"New Infection Chain and ConfuserEx-Based Obfuscation for DarkCloud Stealer","description":"DarkCloud Stealer's delivery has shifted. We explore three different attack chains that use ConfuserEx obfuscation and a final payload in Visual Basic 6.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain\/","datePublished":"August 7, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nUnit 42 researchers recently observed a shift in the delivery method in the distribution of DarkCloud Stealer and the obfuscation techniques used to complicate analysis. First seen in early April 2025, these new methods and techniques include an additional infection chain for DarkCloud Stealer. This chain involves obfuscation by ConfuserEx and a final payload written in Visual Basic 6 (VB6).\r\n\r\nWe previously identified a series of attacks linked to the distribution of DarkCloud Stealer. It also leveraged AutoIt to bypass detection systems. We documented these details in DarkCloud Stealer: Comprehensive Analysis of a New Attack Chain That Employs AutoIt.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced WildFire\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering\r\n \tAdvanced DNS Security\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM\r\n \tCortex Cloud\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nInfostealers, Anti-analysis\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDelivery Mechanism and Updated Infection Chain\r\nWe have observed three slightly different attack chains delivering the same final DarkCloud Stealer payload in recent attacks.\r\n\r\nEach attack chain starts with a phishing email that contains either a tarball (TAR), Roshal (RAR) or a 7-Zip (7Z) archive. Both the TAR or RAR versions contain a JavaScript (JS) file, while the 7Z version contains a Windows Script File (WSF). The threat actor is at a point in development that, for all infection chain paths, almost every stage is obfuscated or protected.\r\n\r\nFigure 1 shows an overview of the different infection chains of these recent DarkCloud Stealer campaigns.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150475\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 1. Infection chain of recent DarkCloud attacks.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn the chains initiated by a JS script, executing the script downloads and executes a PowerShell (PS1) file from an open directory server. The PS1 file then drops an executable (EXE) file that is the ConfuserEx-protected version of the final DarkCloud payload. Looking at the JS file here in Figure 2, the script is obfuscated by the tool javascript-obfuscator.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150486\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. JS downloader in its original obfuscated form.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 3 below shows the deobfuscated version of the same script. In summary, the script:\r\n\r\n \tUses ActiveXObject('MSXML2.XMLHTTP') object to obtain the next stage PS1 script at hxxp[:]\/\/176.65.142[.]190\/BLACKYY\/newbag.ps1\r\n \tUses ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject') object to drop the PS1 file as a random 8-character lowercase name in the C:\\Temp folder.\r\n \tUses ActiveXObject('WScript.Shell') object to run a PowerShell command to execute the PS1 file.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150497\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. Unobfuscated JS downloader.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 4 illustrates an open directory server hosting many malicious PS1 files. In this case, the kay.ps1 is the next stage PS1 sample that the JS script downloaded and executed.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150508\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"552\"] Figure 4. Open directory server hosting PS1 files.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe infection chain initiated by a 7Z archive drops a WSF file. The WSF file mainly consists of a single &lt;job&gt; tag, which contains a &lt;script language=\"JScript\"&gt; tag. The JScript code is again heavily obfuscated, but in a different way than the JS file shown in Figure 2. It also uses ActiveXObject objects to download and execute a PS1 file from the same open directory server. However, the PS1 script associated with this WSF downloader is different.\r\n\r\nNext, we will focus on the JS-based infection chain that runs the kay.ps1 PowerShell script. This PS1 also has two layers of encryption scheme. Figure 5 shows partial code snippets from the first layer. The snippet uses Invoke-Expression (a PowerShell command that executes a string as if it were a command) to invoke another PowerShell expression that is both Base64-encoded and AES-encrypted.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150519\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1782\"] Figure 5. First layer of the PS1 script.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 6 shows a code snippet from the invoked PS1 expression, revealing its core functionality. The code reveals that an EXE file is written to the %tmp% folder with a randomly generated 8-character upper- or lower-case filename. The script then executes the dropped EXE file using the Start-Process command.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150530\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 6. Second layer of the PS1 script.[\/caption]\r\nDarkCloud Technical Analysis: Expanded View\r\nIn the following section, we delve deeper into the analysis of the 32-bit .NET malware sample. This malware sample contains the final DarkCloud executable written in VB6 and wrapped in a layer of ConfuserEx obfuscation.\r\nStage One: Initial ConfuserEx Obfuscation\r\nConfuserEx 2 is an open-source protector for .NET applications. Files protected with ConfuserEx are watermarked with a ConfusedByAttribute attribute. ConfuserEx comes with many features and protections such as:\r\n\r\n \tAnti-tampering (method encryption): This protects the application from unauthorized modification. This is accomplished by only decrypting the code of method bodies at runtime. This decryption is performed in the module constructor (&lt;Module&gt;.cctor), which executes before reaching the main entry point.\r\n \tSymbol renaming: This changes class, method and variable names to random, meaningless, non-American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) printable identifiers.\r\n \tControl flow obfuscation: This alters the code structure with opaque predicates (cf. control flow flattening).\r\n \tMethod reference hiding: This is also known as proxy call method obfuscation (this will be later described in more detail).\r\n \tConstant encoding: This encodes constants (e.g., strings using fixed reversible transformations.\r\n\r\nThe malware author applied these protections to the analyzed malware sample.\r\n\r\nFirst, we can adapt the AntiTamperKiller code to defeat anti-tampering protection. This transformed the sample's .NET code, as Figure 7 shows.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150541\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"646\"] Figure 7. The original sample depicting anti-tampering protection applied.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe method body code consists of bogus invalid .NET instructions into the deobfuscated code seen in Figure 8, where the real method body code is now visible. In particular, we extracted the specific parameters of the anti-tampering protection:\r\n\r\n \tKey 1: 0xc225d58c\r\n \tKey 2: 0xa2e32024\r\n \tKey 3: 0xdcc95ec9\r\n \tKey 4: 0x00000000\r\n \tName hash: 0xe0cbeae4\r\n \tInternal key: 0x3dbb2819\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150552\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"646\"] Figure 8. Sample with anti-tampering protection removed.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nNext, we still have more cleanup work to do on the partially deobfuscated sample. We then applied de4dot-cex (a fork of de4dot, a generic .NET deobfuscator and unpacker, which includes support for ConfuserEx deobfuscation) to the sample, using the -p crx command-line switch. This transforms the .NET sample\u2019s code seen in Figure 8 into the code shown in Figure 9, by renaming the obfuscated symbols and reverting the control flow flattening.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150563\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"651\"] Figure 9. Partially deobfuscated sample, after applying de4dot-cex.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThereafter, proxy call methods can be fixed using the proxy call remover tool. Proxy call method obfuscation is a technique that replaces direct method calls with calls to intermediate (i.e., proxy) methods. These proxy methods often do almost nothing besides forwarding the original call. However, they make control flow more difficult for the analyst to follow, thus hindering the code decompilation process. This reduces code readability and increases the effort required to fully understand the entire program logic.\r\n\r\nRemoving these proxy call methods resulted in the simplified code seen in Figure 10. The Class8.smethod_10 method is revealed as the standard Convert.FromBase64String method.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150574\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"710\"] Figure 10. Deobfuscated sample with proxy calls removed.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nEventually, the final DarkCloud VB6 payload (which is in Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES) encrypted form shown in Figure 11) is decrypted and executed.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150585\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"637\"] Figure 11. Final VB6 payload in 3DES-encrypted form.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe Base64-encoded key, initialization vector (IV) and ciphertext are stored as strings within the &lt;Module&gt;.byte_0 variable in Length-Value format, as shown in Figure 12.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150596\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 12. &lt;Module&gt;.byte_0 variable in Length-Value format.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe standard Type-Length-Value (TLV) format (TLV) format typically includes a type identifier, but in this case, it\u2019s omitted because all values are strings. For instance, the cryptographic key iA9B1uKFddQdqiLSSuzvD2GhL1o2Jv+v (also shown in Figure 11) is stored as a 32-byte string. The length is specified at offset 60 in little-endian format, with the string value beginning at offset 64.\r\n\r\nThe &lt;Module&gt;.byte_0 variable value is initialized in the module constructor (&lt;Module&gt;.cctor), through a series of exclusive OR (XOR) and bitwise (arithmetic bit shift) operations on a hard-coded 100,560-element unsigned integer array. After initialization, other generic .NET methods, each accepting a single integer id as parameter, use this array to index the initialized &lt;Module&gt;.byte_0 variable and return a string. Figure 13 shows one such method, &lt;Module&gt;.smethod_6.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150607\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"602\"] Figure 13. Example generic .NET method providing a string lookup by id on the &lt;Module&gt;.byte_0 variable.[\/caption]\r\nStage Two: Final VB6 Payload\r\nRunPE, or process hollowing, is a process injection technique. Process hollowing works by first creating a fresh instance of a (usually legitimate) process in a suspended state. The process memory is then overwritten with code from another (usually malicious) executable. Subsequently, the process thread resumes at the entry point of the overwritten code, so that the malicious code now runs in the context of the benign process.\r\n\r\nThe ConfuserEx protected process uses process hollowing to inject the final VB6 payload. After decryption, the final VB6 payload named holographies.exe, is injected into a new native Portable Executable (PE) process spawned by the initial ConfuserEx process. The process used for injection is RegAsm.exe, a legitimate utility that comes with the default installed .NET Framework SDK on Windows.\r\n\r\nThe presence of the string DarkCloud within the final VB6 payload (shown in Figure 14) confirms its affiliation with the DarkCloud malware family.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_150618\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 14. DARKCLOUD Unicode string in little-endian format (UTF16-LE) embedded within the final VB6 payload file.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nAdditionally, critical strings within the payload are encrypted using the Rivest Cipher 4 (RC4) stream cipher algorithm, with each ciphertext typically using a unique key. For instance, the ciphertext 58364B6DB1C7D797DFA59186B4 paired with the key sMgSInEGpSAgkfcMSUPDDFCVSTyhowuHorsctkyTMYZh decrypts to the string WScript.Shell. These sensitive strings can be broadly categorized as:\r\n\r\n \tRegular expressions\r\n \tCredit card names\r\n \tRegistry paths\r\n \tDirectory and file paths (including file extensions)\r\n \tTelegram API credentials (used for C2 purposes)\r\n \tOther miscellaneous strings\r\n\r\nConclusion\r\nDarkCloud Stealer is typical of an evolution in cyberthreats, leveraging obfuscation techniques and intricate payload structures to evade traditional detection mechanisms. The developers of the malware complicated its analysis by adopting ConfuserEx and a VB6 payload in its infection chain.\r\n\r\nThe shift in delivery methods observed in April 2025 indicates an evolving evasion strategy. This highlights the need for security professionals to adopt proactive, behavior-based approaches to threat detection and mitigation.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM are designed to prevent the execution of known malicious malware, and also prevent the execution of unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.\r\n \tCortex Cloud customers are better protected from DarkCloud Stealer through the proper placement of Cortex Cloud XDR endpoint agent and serverless agents within a cloud environment. Designed to protect a cloud\u2019s posture and runtime operations against these threats, Cortex Cloud helps detect and prevent the malicious operations or configuration alterations or exploitations discussed within this article.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 00080005045107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nFile Type\r\nSHA256 Hash\r\n\r\n\r\nRAR archive\r\nbd8c0b0503741c17d75ce560a10eeeaa0cdd21dff323d9f1644c62b7b8eb43d9\r\n\r\n\r\nTAR archive\r\n9588c9a754574246d179c9fb05fea9dc5762c855a3a2a4823b402217f82a71c1\r\n\r\n\r\nJS file\r\n6b8a4c3d4a4a0a3aea50037744c5fec26a38d3fb6a596d006457f1c51bbc75c7\r\n\r\n\r\nPS1 file\r\nF6d9198bd707c49454b83687af926ccb8d13c7e43514f59eac1507467e8fb140\r\n\r\n\r\nWSF file\r\n72d3de12a0aa8ce87a64a70807f0769c332816f27dcf8286b91e6819e2197aa8\r\n\r\n\r\n7Z archive\r\nfa598e761201582d41a73d174eb5edad10f709238d99e0bf698da1601c71d1ca\r\n\r\n\r\n7Z archive\r\n2bd43f839d5f77f22f619395461c1eeaee9234009b475231212b88bd510d00b7\r\n\r\n\r\nInitial ConfuserEx .NET EXE file\r\n24552408d849799b2cac983d499b1f32c88c10f88319339d0eec00fb01bb19b4\r\n\r\n\r\nFinal DarkCloud VB6 EXE file\r\nce3a3e46ca65d779d687c7e58fb4a2eb784e5b1b4cebe33dbb2bf37cccb6f194\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n \tMalware distribution URL hxxp[:]\/\/176.65.142[.]190\r\n \tC2 URL hxxps[:]\/\/api.telegram[.]org\/bot7684022823:AAFw0jHSu-b4qs6N7yC88nUOR8ovPrCdIrs\/sendMessage?chat_id=6542615755\r\n\r\nAdditional Resources\r\n\r\n \tDarkCloud Stealer: Comprehensive Analysis of a New Attack Chain That Employs AutoIt \u2013 Unit 42, Palo Alto Networks\r\n \t.NET Hooking - Harmonizing Managed Territory \u2013 Ji\u0159\u00ed Vinopal, Check Point Research\r\n\r\n&nbsp;","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2025\/08\/04_Malware_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Pranay Kumar Chhaparwal"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Benjamin Chang"},{"@type":"Person","name":"Lee Wei Yeong"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-image-style-inline-css'>
.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image{margin-bottom:0}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image :where(img){height:auto;max-width:100%;vertical-align:bottom}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow .wp-block-co-authors-plus-image :where(img){vertical-align:middle}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image:is(.alignfull,.alignwide) :where(img){width:100%}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image:is(.alignleft,.alignright){display:table}.wp-block-co-authors-plus-image.aligncenter{display:table;margin-inline:auto}

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

    </head>
<body class="wp-singular post-template-default single single-post postid-150463 single-format-standard wp-theme-unit42-v6 no-sidebar">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>

<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->



<main class="main">

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fnew-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Facebook" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:share:facebook"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-fb-share.svg" alt="Facebook Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fnew-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain%2F&#038;title=New%20Infection%20Chain%20and%20ConfuserEx-Based%20Obfuscation%20for%20DarkCloud%20Stealer" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in LinkedIn" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:share:linkedin"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-linkedin-share.svg" alt="LinkedIn Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fnew-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain%2F&#038;text=New%20Infection%20Chain%20and%20ConfuserEx-Based%20Obfuscation%20for%20DarkCloud%20Stealer" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fnew-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=New%20Infection%20Chain%20and%20ConfuserEx-Based%20Obfuscation%20for%20DarkCloud%20Stealer%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fnew-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-150463-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Unit 42 researchers recently observed a shift in the delivery method in the distribution of DarkCloud Stealer and the obfuscation techniques used to complicate analysis. First seen in early April 2025, these new methods and techniques include an additional infection chain for DarkCloud Stealer. This chain involves obfuscation by ConfuserEx and a final payload written in Visual Basic 6 (VB6).</p>
<p>We previously identified a series of attacks linked to the distribution of DarkCloud Stealer. It also leveraged AutoIt to bypass detection systems. We documented these details in <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/darkcloud-stealer-and-obfuscated-autoit-scripting/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">DarkCloud Stealer: Comprehensive Analysis of a New Attack Chain That Employs AutoIt</a>.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Cloud</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/infostealer/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Infostealers</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/anti-analysis/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anti-analysis</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-150463-_wou02ajdics4"></a>Delivery Mechanism and Updated Infection Chain</h2>
<p>We have observed three slightly different attack chains delivering the same final DarkCloud Stealer payload in recent attacks.</p>
<p>Each attack chain starts with a phishing email that contains either a tarball (TAR), Roshal (RAR) or a 7-Zip (7Z) archive. Both the TAR or RAR versions contain a JavaScript (JS) file, while the 7Z version contains a Windows Script File (WSF). The threat actor is at a point in development that, for all infection chain paths, almost every stage is obfuscated or protected.</p>
<p>Figure 1 shows an overview of the different infection chains of these recent DarkCloud Stealer campaigns.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150475" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150475" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150475 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-464937-150463-1.png" alt="Flowchart showing a cybersecurity attack sequence starting from a phishing email with various file types (RAR, JS, TAR), leading to an Open Directory Server, engaging a PowerShell script (PS1), and culminating in the execution of a malware payload process. The process begins with an EXE file, labeled as the initial payload ConfuserEx, which launches the official .Net RegAsm tool, and results in a second injected EXE known as the final payload VB6." width="1000" height="325" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-464937-150463-1.png 1044w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-464937-150463-1-786x255.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-464937-150463-1-768x249.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150475" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Infection chain of recent DarkCloud attacks.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the chains initiated by a JS script, executing the script downloads and executes a PowerShell (PS1) file from an open directory server. The PS1 file then drops an executable (EXE) file that is the <a href="https://yck1509.github.io/ConfuserEx/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">ConfuserEx</a>-protected version of the final DarkCloud payload. Looking at the JS file here in Figure 2, the script is obfuscated by the tool <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://github.com/javascript-obfuscator/javascript-obfuscator" target="_blank" rel="noopener">javascript-obfuscator</a></span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150486" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150486" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150486 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-468495-150463-2.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer monitor displaying multiple lines of colorful computer code on a black background." width="1000" height="310" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-468495-150463-2.png 1632w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-468495-150463-2-786x244.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-468495-150463-2-768x238.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-468495-150463-2-1536x476.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150486" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. JS downloader in its original obfuscated form.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 3 below shows the deobfuscated version of the same script. In summary, the script:</p>
<ul>
<li>Uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ActiveXObject('MSXML2.XMLHTTP')</span> object to obtain the next stage PS1 script at <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxp[:]//176.65.142[.]190/BLACKYY/newbag.ps1</span></li>
<li>Uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ActiveXObject('Scripting.FileSystemObject')</span> object to drop the PS1 file as a random 8-character lowercase name in the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\Temp</span> folder.</li>
<li>Uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ActiveXObject('WScript.Shell')</span> object to run a PowerShell command to execute the PS1 file.</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_150497" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150497" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150497 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3.png" alt="A screenshot displaying many lines of code that involve JavaScript functions related to network activities and error handling, written in a text editor with syntax highlighting." width="1000" height="1133" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3.png 1444w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3-388x440.png 388w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3-618x700.png 618w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3-768x870.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-471616-150463-3-1356x1536.png 1356w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150497" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Unobfuscated JS downloader.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 4 illustrates an open directory server hosting many malicious PS1 files. In this case, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kay.ps1</span> is the next stage PS1 sample that the JS script downloaded and executed.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150508" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150508" style="width: 552px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150508 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-475082-150463-4.png" alt="Screenshot of a web directory listing. It is the index for blackyy. It is on Apache/2.4.58 (Win64) OpenSSL/1.1.1j PHP/8.0.3 Server at 176 dot 65 dot 142 dot 190 Port 80, displaying various files with details on the last modified dates and file sizes." width="552" height="471" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-475082-150463-4.png 552w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-475082-150463-4-516x440.png 516w" sizes="(max-width: 552px) 100vw, 552px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150508" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Open directory server hosting PS1 files.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The infection chain initiated by a 7Z archive drops a WSF file. The WSF file mainly consists of a single <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;job&gt;</span> tag, which contains a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;script language="JScript"&gt;</span> tag. The JScript code is again heavily obfuscated, but in a different way than the JS file shown in Figure 2. It also uses ActiveXObject objects to download and execute a PS1 file from the same open directory server. However, the PS1 script associated with this WSF downloader is different.</p>
<p>Next, we will focus on the JS-based infection chain that runs the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">kay.ps1</span> PowerShell script. This PS1 also has two layers of encryption scheme. Figure 5 shows partial code snippets from the first layer. The snippet uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/invoke-expression?view=powershell-7.5" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Invoke-Expression</a></span> (a PowerShell command that executes a string as if it were a command) to invoke another PowerShell expression that is both Base64-encoded and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Encryption_Standard" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AES</a>-encrypted.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150519" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150519" style="width: 1782px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150519 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-478551-150463-5.png" alt="Screenshot of computer code involving Base64 encoding and decryption processes. The PowerShell script first layer. " width="1782" height="316" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-478551-150463-5.png 1782w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-478551-150463-5-786x139.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-478551-150463-5-768x136.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-478551-150463-5-1536x272.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1782px) 100vw, 1782px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150519" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. First layer of the PS1 script.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 6 shows a code snippet from the invoked PS1 expression, revealing its core functionality. The code reveals that an EXE file is written to the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">%tmp%</span> folder with a randomly generated 8-character upper- or lower-case filename. The script then executes the dropped EXE file using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Start-Process</span> command.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150530" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150530" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150530 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-481333-150463-6.png" alt="Screenshot of white code on a black background. The PowerShell script second layer. " width="1000" height="57" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-481333-150463-6.png 1872w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-481333-150463-6-786x45.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-481333-150463-6-768x43.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-481333-150463-6-1536x87.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150530" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Second layer of the PS1 script.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-150463-_wven14kmgum2"></a>DarkCloud Technical Analysis: Expanded View</h2>
<p>In the following section, we delve deeper into the analysis of the 32-bit .NET malware sample. This malware sample contains the final DarkCloud executable written in VB6 and wrapped in a layer of ConfuserEx obfuscation.</p>
<h3><a id="post-150463-_vzphjungbwj"></a>Stage One: Initial ConfuserEx Obfuscation</h3>
<p>ConfuserEx 2 is an open-source protector for .NET applications. Files protected with ConfuserEx are <a href="https://github.com/yck1509/ConfuserEx/blob/master/Confuser.Core/ConfuserEngine.cs#L303" target="_blank" rel="noopener">watermarked</a> with a <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ConfusedByAttribute</span> attribute. ConfuserEx comes with many features and protections such as:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://blog.threat.zone/deobfuscation-technical-analysis-of-confuserex-2" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anti-tampering</a> (method encryption): This protects the application from unauthorized modification. This is accomplished by <em>only</em> decrypting the code of method bodies at runtime. This decryption is performed in the module constructor (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.cctor</span>), which executes before reaching the main entry point.</li>
<li>Symbol renaming: This changes class, method and variable names to random, meaningless, non-American Standard Code for Information Interchange (ASCII) printable identifiers.</li>
<li>Control flow obfuscation: This alters the code structure with <a href="https://unprotect.it/technique/opaque-predicate" target="_blank" rel="noopener">opaque predicates</a> (cf. <a href="https://jscrambler.com/blog/jscrambler-101-control-flow-flattening" target="_blank" rel="noopener">control flow flattening</a>).</li>
<li>Method reference hiding: This is also known as proxy call method obfuscation (this will be later described in more detail).</li>
<li>Constant encoding: This encodes constants (e.g., strings using fixed reversible transformations.</li>
</ul>
<p>The malware author applied these protections to the analyzed malware sample.</p>
<p>First, we can adapt the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://www.cnblogs.com/wwh1004/p/17620443.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">AntiTamperKiller</a></span> code to defeat anti-tampering protection. This transformed the sample's .NET code, as Figure 7 shows.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150541" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150541" style="width: 646px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150541 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-484091-150463-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer screen displaying code in an IDE with error messages, specifically a DecompilerException, indicating non-generic decompiling issues. The code includes hex addresses and assembly language elements." width="646" height="479" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-484091-150463-7.png 646w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-484091-150463-7-593x440.png 593w" sizes="(max-width: 646px) 100vw, 646px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150541" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. The original sample depicting anti-tampering protection applied.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The method body code consists of bogus invalid .NET instructions into the deobfuscated code seen in Figure 8, where the real method body code is now visible. In particular, we extracted the specific parameters of the anti-tampering protection:</p>
<ul>
<li>Key 1: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xc225d58c</span></li>
<li>Key 2: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xa2e32024</span></li>
<li>Key 3: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xdcc95ec9</span></li>
<li>Key 4: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x00000000</span></li>
<li>Name hash: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0xe0cbeae4</span></li>
<li>Internal key: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0x3dbb2819</span></li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_150552" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150552" style="width: 646px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150552 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-487685-150463-8.png" alt="A screenshot of a computer screen displaying code in a software development environment. The code includes loops and conditional statements. " width="646" height="590" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-487685-150463-8.png 646w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-487685-150463-8-482x440.png 482w" sizes="(max-width: 646px) 100vw, 646px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150552" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Sample with anti-tampering protection removed.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Next, we still have more cleanup work to do on the partially deobfuscated sample. We then applied <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://github.com/ViRb3/de4dot-cex" target="_blank" rel="noopener">de4dot-cex</a></span> (a fork of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://github.com/de4dot/de4dot" target="_blank" rel="noopener">de4dot</a></span>, a generic .NET deobfuscator and unpacker, which includes support for ConfuserEx deobfuscation) to the sample, using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">-p crx</span> command-line switch. This transforms the .NET sample’s code seen in Figure 8 into the code shown in Figure 9, by renaming the obfuscated symbols and reverting the control flow flattening.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150563" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150563" style="width: 651px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150563 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-490362-150463-9.png" alt="Image of a snippet of computer code showing functions and variable assignments within a Main method." width="651" height="126" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150563" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Partially deobfuscated sample, after applying <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://github.com/ViRb3/de4dot-cex" target="_blank" rel="noopener">de4dot-cex</a></span>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Thereafter, proxy call methods can be fixed using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://github.com/Kaidoz/ProxyCall-Remover" target="_blank" rel="noopener">proxy call remover</a></span> tool. Proxy call method obfuscation is a technique that replaces direct method calls with calls to intermediate (i.e., proxy) methods. These proxy methods often do almost nothing besides forwarding the original call. However, they make control flow more difficult for the analyst to follow, thus hindering the code decompilation process. This reduces code readability and increases the effort required to fully understand the entire program logic.</p>
<p>Removing these proxy call methods resulted in the simplified code seen in Figure 10. The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Class8.smethod_10</span> method is revealed as the standard <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Convert.FromBase64String</span> method.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150574" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150574" style="width: 710px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150574 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-493829-150463-10.png" alt="A screenshot of programming code displayed on a digital screen, featuring functions and methods related to data conversion and string manipulation." width="710" height="126" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150574" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Deobfuscated sample with proxy calls removed.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Eventually, the final DarkCloud VB6 payload (which is in <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triple_DES" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Triple Data Encryption Standard (3DES)</a> encrypted form shown in Figure 11) is decrypted and executed.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150585" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150585" style="width: 637px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150585 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-497302-150463-11.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer code in a development environment, featuring several lines that include methods for converting Base64 strings." width="637" height="182" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150585" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. Final VB6 payload in 3DES-encrypted form.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The Base64-encoded key, initialization vector (IV) and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ciphertext</span> are stored as strings within the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.byte_0</span> variable in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Length-Value</span> format, as shown in Figure 12.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150596" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150596" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150596 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-500555-150463-12.png" alt="Hexadecimal values displayed in pink and green on a black background, with some ASCII characters visible on the right side." width="1000" height="424" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-500555-150463-12.png 1268w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-500555-150463-12-786x333.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-500555-150463-12-768x326.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150596" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.byte_0</span> variable in Length-Value format.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The standard <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-length-value" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Type-Length-Value (TLV) format</a> (TLV) format typically includes a type identifier, but in this case, it’s omitted because all values are strings. For instance, the cryptographic key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">iA9B1uKFddQdqiLSSuzvD2GhL1o2Jv+v</span> (also shown in Figure 11) is stored as a 32-byte string. The length is specified at offset 60 in little-endian format, with the string value beginning at offset 64.</p>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.byte_0</span> variable value is initialized in the module constructor (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.cctor</span>), through a series of exclusive OR (XOR) and <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitwise_operation" target="_blank" rel="noopener">bitwise</a> (arithmetic bit shift) operations on a hard-coded 100,560-element unsigned integer array. After initialization, other <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/csharp/programming-guide/generics/generic-methods" target="_blank" rel="noopener">generic</a> .NET methods, each accepting a single integer id as parameter, use this array to index the initialized <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.byte_0</span> variable and return a string. Figure 13 shows one such method, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.smethod_6</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150607" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150607" style="width: 602px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150607 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-503254-150463-13.png" alt="A screenshot of many lines of code showing with several lines including conditionals, loops, and function definitions." width="602" height="871" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-503254-150463-13.png 602w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-503254-150463-13-304x440.png 304w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-503254-150463-13-484x700.png 484w" sizes="(max-width: 602px) 100vw, 602px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150607" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Example generic .NET method providing a string lookup by <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">id</span> on the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">&lt;Module&gt;.byte_0</span> variable.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-150463-_fhq2xq8n858x"></a>Stage Two: Final VB6 Payload</h3>
<p><a href="https://www.esentire.com/blog/pure-crypter-malware-analysis-99-problems-but-detection-aint-one" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RunPE</a>, or <a href="https://unprotect.it/technique/process-hollowing-runpe" target="_blank" rel="noopener">process</a> <a href="https://hackingarticles.in/process-hollowing-mitret1055-012" target="_blank" rel="noopener">hollowing</a>, is a process injection technique. Process hollowing works by first creating a fresh instance of a (usually legitimate) process in a suspended state. The process memory is then overwritten with code from another (usually malicious) executable. Subsequently, the process thread resumes at the entry point of the overwritten code, so that the malicious code now runs in the context of the benign process.</p>
<p>The ConfuserEx protected process uses process hollowing to inject the final VB6 payload. After decryption, the final VB6 payload named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">holographies.exe</span>, is injected into a new native Portable Executable (PE) process spawned by the initial ConfuserEx process. The process used for injection is <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">RegAsm.exe</span>, a <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/framework/tools/regasm-exe-assembly-registration-tool" target="_blank" rel="noopener">legitimate</a> utility that comes with the default installed .NET Framework SDK on Windows.</p>
<p>The presence of the string DarkCloud within the final VB6 payload (shown in Figure 14) confirms its affiliation with the DarkCloud malware family.</p>
<figure id="attachment_150618" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-150618" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-150618 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-506732-150463-14.png" alt="Hexadecimal and ASCII data representations on a computer screen, including highlighted sections spelling out DARK CLOUD." width="1000" height="333" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-506732-150463-14.png 1268w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-506732-150463-14-786x262.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/word-image-506732-150463-14-768x256.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-150618" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. DARKCLOUD Unicode string in little-endian format (UTF16-LE) embedded within the final VB6 payload file.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Additionally, critical strings within the payload are encrypted using the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RC4" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Rivest Cipher 4 (RC4)</a> stream cipher algorithm, with each ciphertext typically using a unique key. For instance, the ciphertext <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">58364B6DB1C7D797DFA59186B4</span> paired with the key <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sMgSInEGpSAgkfcMSUPDDFCVSTyhowuHorsctkyTMYZh</span> decrypts to the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">WScript.Shell</span>. These sensitive strings can be broadly categorized as:</p>
<ul>
<li>Regular expressions</li>
<li>Credit card names</li>
<li>Registry paths</li>
<li>Directory and file paths (including file extensions)</li>
<li>Telegram API credentials (used for C2 purposes)</li>
<li>Other miscellaneous strings</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-150463-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>DarkCloud Stealer is typical of an evolution in cyberthreats, leveraging obfuscation techniques and intricate payload structures to evade traditional detection mechanisms. The developers of the malware complicated its analysis by adopting ConfuserEx and a VB6 payload in its infection chain.</p>
<p>The shift in delivery methods observed in April 2025 indicates an evolving evasion strategy. This highlights the need for security professionals to adopt proactive, behavior-based approaches to threat detection and mitigation.</p>
<h3><a id="post-150463-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li>The<a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener"> Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> are designed to prevent the execution of known malicious malware, and also prevent the execution of unknown malware using Behavioral Threat Protection and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cloud" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex Cloud</a> customers are better protected from DarkCloud Stealer through the proper placement of Cortex Cloud <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-CLOUD/Cortex-Cloud-Runtime-Security-Documentation/Endpoint-protection" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XDR endpoint agent</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XSIAM/Cortex-XSIAM-Premium-Documentation/Use-cases" target="_blank" rel="noopener">serverless agents</a> within a cloud environment. Designed to protect a cloud’s posture and runtime operations against these threats, Cortex Cloud helps detect and prevent the malicious operations or configuration alterations or exploitations discussed within this article.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 00080005045107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>

                  </a>

              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of infiltration of global telecom networks. A laptop screen displaying a complex graphical interface with red and white circular patterns, possibly indicating a cybersecurity or data analysis program. The keyboard is backlit in red, set against a dimly lit room with blurred red lighting in the background." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/03_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-actor-groups/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:The Covert Operator&#039;s Playbook: Infiltration of Global Telecom Networks:Threat Actor Groups"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/threat-actor-groups.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Actor Groups</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-29T21:00:16+00:00">July 29, 2025</time></span>

                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/social-engineering/" title="social engineering" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:Fix the Click: Preventing the ClickFix Attack Vector:social engineering">Social engineering</a>

                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of LNK malware. Digital abstract background featuring binary codes and connections, highlighted in blue tones in the shape of a skull, representing data and network concepts." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/01_Malware_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:Windows Shortcut (LNK) Malware Strategies:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-02T10:00:37+00:00">July 2, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/lnk-malware/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:Windows Shortcut (LNK) Malware Strategies">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Windows Shortcut (LNK) Malware Strategies</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/microsoft-windows/" title="Microsoft Windows" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:Windows Shortcut (LNK) Malware Strategies:Microsoft Windows">Microsoft Windows</a>

                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/08_Nation-State-cyberattacks_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of Iranian-backed threat groups and hacktivists.               <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/top-cyberthreats/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="new-darkcloud-stealer-infection-chain:related-resources:Threat Brief: Escalation of Cyber Risk Related to Iran (Updated June 30):High Profile Threats"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/top-threats.svg" alt=" category icon">High Profile Threats</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-06-25T18:00:13+00:00">June 25, 2025</time></span>
